questions.question: What technique anticipates needed I/O operations?
questions.explanation: I/O prefetching loads data before explicit requests. It improves sequential access performance.

questions.question: What schedules I/O for minimal seek time?
questions.explanation: I/O schedulers reorder requests to minimize seek times. They balance fairness and performance.

questions.question: What combines small writes into larger operations?
questions.explanation: Write coalescing merges adjacent writes. It reduces total I/O operations.

questions.question: What RAID level provides both striping and mirroring?
questions.explanation: RAID 10 combines RAID 1 and RAID 0. It offers both redundancy and performance.

questions.question: What technique bypasses kernel buffering?
questions.explanation: Direct I/O transfers data straight between devices and user space. It avoids kernel buffer copies.

questions.question: What multiplexes I/O on multiple descriptors?
questions.explanation: Select monitors multiple file descriptors for I/O readiness. It enables efficient multiplexing.

questions.question: What Linux mechanism provides asynchronous I/O?
questions.explanation: io_uring provides efficient asynchronous I/O. It uses shared ring buffers for communication.

questions.question: What optimizes disk writes by delaying and reordering?
questions.explanation: Write-back caching acknowledges writes before disk completion. It improves performance but risks data loss.

questions.question: What ensures writes complete before acknowledging?
questions.explanation: Write-through caching waits for disk confirmation. It sacrifices performance for durability.

questions.question: What technique removes duplicated disk blocks?
questions.explanation: Deduplication stores identical blocks once. It saves storage space.
